articles.headline: Europe’s Economic Powerhouse Drifts East
articles.snippet: The robust German economy is deploying money and management time outside the euro area.
articles.abstract: The robust German economy is deploying money and management time outside the euro area.
articles.lead_paragraph: DITZINGEN, GERMANY — Germany has long sat at the center of the European economy, but Europe is no longer as central to Germany as it used to be.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Judy Dempsey

articles.headline: Murdoch Aides Long Tried to Blunt Scandal Over Hacking
articles.snippet: A small group of executives at News Corporation pursued strategies for years that had the effect of obscuring the extent of wrongdoing in Britain’s best-selling tabloid.
articles.abstract: A small group of executives at News Corporation pursued strategies for years that had the effect of obscuring the extent of wrongdoing in Britain’s best-selling tabloid.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two days before it emerged that The News of the World had hacked the cellphone of a murdered schoolgirl, igniting a scandal that has shaken the media empire of Rupert Murdoch, his son James told friends that he thought the worst of the troubles were behind him. And he was confident that the News Corporation’s $12 billion bid for the satellite company British Sky Broadcasting would go through, according to a person present.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Dodd-Frank Under Fire a Year Later
articles.snippet: There are two dozen bills in Congress to dismantle parts of the law, and Senate Republicans refuse to consider nominations for posts at several regulatory agencies.
articles.abstract: There are two dozen bills in Congress to dismantle parts of the law, and Senate Republicans refuse to consider nominations for posts at several regulatory agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the year since the passage of a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system after the financial crisis, the stock market is up, banking profits have grown and institutions that invest on behalf of average Americans are praising the tougher stance in Washington.

articles.headline: China’s Treasury Holdings Make U.S. Woes Its Own
articles.snippet: Beijing has too much invested in American debt to do much more but continue to buy and grumble.
articles.abstract: Beijing has too much invested in American debt to do much more but continue to buy and grumble.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — However grim Washington’s debt and deficit negotiations may seem to Americans, the impasse is nearly as disturbing for China.

articles.headline: In Debt Crisis, a Legislative Trick Up the Sleeve
articles.snippet: The idea would allow Republicans to accede to an increase in the government’s debt limit without actually voting for it or giving in to President Obama’s demand for tax increases as part of any deal.
articles.abstract: The idea would allow Republicans to accede to an increase in the government’s debt limit without actually voting for it or giving in to President Obama’s demand for tax increases as part of any deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Republicans and Democrats still deeply divided over how to shrink the budget deficit and the national debt, the only way for them to avoid a financial crisis at this late date may be to perform a legislative magic trick.

articles.headline: 24 Small Towns May Lose Air Service
articles.snippet: Delta Air Lines says half-full planes and the high cost of fuel are leading it to reduce service to rural America.
articles.abstract: Delta Air Lines says half-full planes and the high cost of fuel are leading it to reduce service to rural America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rural America, already struggling to recover from the recession and the flight of its young people, is about to take another blow: the loss of its airline service.

articles.headline: As Weather Becomes Big Story, TV Forecasters Play the Hero
articles.snippet: Today’s television weather forecasters, increasingly called meteorologists, are going beyond simply telling people whether to carry an umbrella.
articles.abstract: Today’s television weather forecasters, increasingly called meteorologists, are going beyond simply telling people whether to carry an umbrella.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — One evening in April, Tina Eller had the television on. Glenn Burns, the steely chief meteorologist for WSB-TV, said a tornado was three minutes away from slamming into her community.

articles.headline: Murdochs Deny That They Knew of Illegal Acts
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch insisted to British lawmakers that he had not ordered or hidden unethical practices.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch insisted to British lawmakers that he had not ordered or hidden unethical practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was riveting theater, a newly emboldened parliamentary committee facing off against the 80-year-old Rupert Murdoch, the world’s most powerful media mogul, in a series of exchanges designed to get to the bottom of the phone hacking scandal that has engulfed not just Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation, but also Britain’s political and law-enforcement elite.

articles.headline: After Quake, Japanese Choose Peace of Mind Over Great View
articles.snippet: In Tokyo, unit sales at apartment buildings more than 20 stories tall were down nearly 40 percent from the year before.
articles.abstract: In Tokyo, unit sales at apartment buildings more than 20 stories tall were down nearly 40 percent from the year before.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — From their spacious 24th-floor apartment here, Masako Tsubuku and her husband had a breathtaking view of Mount Fuji.
